item.title: How to make a timer without being an idiot
item.dc:creator: @Aftermath_961 Aftermath
item.description:
@Aftermath_961 wrote:

Looked at the CycleEvents source - the timing method in this thread is more efficient.

On a related note, this is making timer tasks in general, but you could use this idea to make a timed event manager for your server. You could have a Timer object for the entire server which runs TimerTasks, and you could subclass to have specialized TimerTasks for doing large categories of things (e.g. managing animations).

Furthermore, you could have more than one Timer so that groups of related tasks share a timer; then you could disable a certain set of repeated events, for example, without affecting other events.

item.title: How to make a timer without being an idiot
item.dc:creator: @imsuperman05 imsuperman05
item.description:
@imsuperman05 wrote:

I don’t care if this is gravedigging.

Wouldn’t you have to call this method multiple times(Around 10 times) for it to actually execute the print line; (“Run 10 times, it’s time to stop!”);

[code=java] public static void demoRepeatingTask() {
Timer timer = new Timer();
int delayTime = 3000; // Time to wait before starting the timer
int repeatInterval = 300; // Time to wait between runs

            timer.schedule(new TimerTask() {
                    int timesRun;

                    @Override
                    public void run() {
                            timesRun++;
                            System.out.println("Repeating task run " + timesRun + " times.");
                            printTime();
                            
                            if(timesRun >= 10) {
                                    System.out.println("Run 10 times, it's time to stop!");
                                    cancel();
                            }
                    }
            }, delayTime, repeatInterval);
    }[/code]
